text:
DAVID MCKENZIE: I'm here at
one of the biggest temple

fairs in Beijing to explain
just what is at stake if the US
and China get into a trade war.

President Trump has taken
a hard line on China

and could raise import
tariffs across the board
on Chinese goods.

The thing is, if
Trump raises tariffs,

Chinese might raise
them right back.
And that will be a gamble.

Because it'll be more
expensive for the US consumer.

Trump could also name China
as a currency manipulator.

China does sell a
lot more to the US

than it buys, causing
a huge trade deficit.

But lately China has been
raising the value of the Yuan,
not lowering it.
Now just two.
Two please.
[non-english speech].

That gets us, perhaps,
to the meat of the issue.

China's protectionism in
its own industries in China.

The Chinese have long
stopped the US from investing
in key industries.

And that protectionism
could be a place

to start for the two
sides to negotiate
a new trade agreement.
But look at the crowds here.

The power of the
Chinese economy,

the power of the
Chinese consumer,

means that they'd come to any
trade discussion or trade war

from a position of strength
David McKenzie, CNN Beijing.
